title: Taco Log
content: #oakland #restaurants #food WHERE WHAT WHEN THOUGHTS Tacos Sinaloa Shrimp, saudero, carnitas tacos 2025-07-12 The saudero is underrated. ðŸ’³ Tacos Asi Es Colima Carnitas burrito 2025-07-10 Very good, lots of onion. Red sauce is fire roasted. Spicy! $14 ðŸ’³ Taqueria El Mejor Chile Relleno Plate 2025-07-09 Really good, large portions, cheap. Also serve baby burritos. $15 ðŸ’µ Taco El Gordo Al Pastor Burrito 3/13/23 Excellent, good crema, next time try saudero. ðŸ’³ Tacos El Melon Al pastor and birria taco 3/14/23 Cheap, everything was really good. ðŸ’³ Tacos El Novillo Al pastor burrito 3/17/23 LARGE burrito. Next time do asada. ðŸ’³ Los Compadres Asada burrito, asada fries 7/22/23 Best asada in Fruitvale. Friendly guys, really cheap $12. ðŸ’³ Tacos Guadalajara Al pasta burrito 12/19/23 Al pastor was good, red sauce was better than most. ðŸ’³ Related: Town Business

title: brad wiki
content: An uncultivated digital garden published with Obsidian & Github.

title: Useful Linux Terminal
content:
#linux #reference #tech #cli
Shortcut Keys

ctrl + R = reverse search through history
ctrl + L = clear screen
ctrl + U = clear line
ctrl + W/K = clear before/after cursor
ctrl + A/E = jump to begin/end of line
esc + . = argument of the last command
ctrl + X + E = open current line in text editor

Commands
Find and replace in a previous command
Replace a string in the last matching command:
^find^replace

ex:
ssh 192.168.0.7
# do stuff on that server, now move on to the next...
^.7^.8

Return to previous directory
cd -

Re-run previous command with sudo
sudo !!

Refer to last string of previous command
You can use $_ to refer to the last string/argument. ex:
touch /path/to/file
nano $_

Create directories from list
xargs mkdir -p < list.txt

Combine multiple files into one
find . -name '*.txt' -exec cat {} + >> ../combined.txt

List processes with ports open
sudo netstat -tulnp

Human readable CSV output
Input doesn't need to be file, ie. sort instead of cat
cat data.csv | column -t -s -n, | less -S

BSD/MacOS column does not support -n argument, so:
cat data.csv | sed 's/,/ ,/g' | column -t -s, | less -S

Useful Utilities
ncdu
ncurses disk usage analyzer - scans all directories in the path and shows a list sorted by size
